Line 36: Line 36:
===Recognition===
===Recognition===
â
[[Image:Sharbat Gula.png|right|thumb|200px|"Afghan Girl" ([[Sharbat Gula]]) Steve McCurry's most famous picture]]
+
McCurry's most recognized photo is that of "[[Afghan Girl (photo)|Afghan Girl]]", a previously unidentified [[Afghan refugees|Afghan refugee]]. The image itself was named as "the most recognized photograph" in the history of the ''National Geographic'' magazine and her face became famous as the cover photograph on the June 1985 issue. The photo has also been widely used on [[Amnesty International]] brochures, posters, and calendars. The identity of the "Afghan Girl" remained unknown for over 15 years until McCurry and a ''National Geographic'' team located the woman, [[Sharbat Gula]], in 2002.
â
McCurry's most recognized photo is that of "Afghan Girl," a previously unidentified [[Afghan refugees|Afghan refugee]]. The image itself was named as "the most recognized photograph" in the history of the ''National Geographic'' magazine and her face became famous as the cover photograph on the June 1985 issue. The photo has also been widely used on [[Amnesty International]] brochures, posters, and calendars. The identity of the "Afghan Girl" remained unknown for over 15 years until McCurry and a ''National Geographic'' team located the woman, [[Sharbat Gula]], in 2002.
 
Although McCurry shoots both in digital and film, his admitted preference is for transparency film. Based in New York, McCurry offers weekend photography workshops, as well as extended 2-week digital photography workshops in Asia (currently scheduled in Nepal, India, and Burma).
Although McCurry shoots both in digital and film, his admitted preference is for transparency film. Based in New York, McCurry offers weekend photography workshops, as well as extended 2-week digital photography workshops in Asia (currently scheduled in Nepal, India, and Burma).
